profileText: A Representative from Mississippi; born near Liberty, Amite County, Miss., March 29, 1850; attended the common schools and the University of Mississippi at Oxford; engaged in agricultural pursuits; member of the State house of representatives 1878-1882 and 1884-1888; served in the State senate 1889-1896; delegate to the State constitutional convention in 1890; elected as a Democrat to the Fifty-fifth Congress and served from March 4, 1897, until his death in Gloster, Amite County, Miss., October 16, 1898; interment in Gloster Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Love, William Franklin. Does the national honor require us to absolve our creditors from the part of their contract which requires them to take silver dollars of 412 1/2 grains. Washington: [Government Printing Office], 1898.
------. The tariff. Speech ... in the House ... March 31, 1897. Washington: [Government Printing Office], 1897.
------. War tariff. Speech ... in the House ... April 28, 1898. Washington: [Government Printing Office], 1898.

United States. Congress (55th, 3rd session: 1898-1899). Memorial address on the life and character of William F. Love (late Representative from Mississippi) delivered in the House of Representatives and Senate, Fifty-fifth Congress, third session. Washington: Government Printing Office, 1899.

researchRecord.name: In the Henry S. Halbert Papers, 1821-1918, 8.4 cubic feet.

recordLocation.name: Alabama Department of Archives and History
